q.a: the first week i was trying to make one insanely quickly. the second week i was feeling yet again bad and shameful for being unable to execute them at that pace. then for the next 3 weeks or so i was making the song for the video. then, when i began the video, a little tickle in my mind was telling me 'you know that little 3d program i use for occasional little bits of things sometimes, well maybe i should actually just try to start the whole video on there and see what happens.' then i had my mind blown in more different ways and angles than i ever knew existed. 2 months deep into this wild ride, it occured to me that now might actually be the most fine time to go ahead and do what is known as the 'finalcut transition', which long story short means i have to entirely abandon the primary video editing software i have used for the last 5 years. the reason for that is because it was discontinued in 2011. i had been delaying this moment for the past 5 years, because as i always used to say, 'there's never a good time to re-learn everything i know, especially because i've been getting better and better at it every day for the last 5 years.' But, here i was, suddenly doing most of my work in a different program which has the distinct advantage of being available on computers made later than 2014. so being aware of that, a spectacular cascade of events suddenly began to unfold, which i can possibly trace back to viewing a youtube rental of spiderman into the spider verse, for which the only way i could watch it was on a borrowed computer, because my main computer had finally become officially too old to play the movie with ANY browser. that realization, combined with seeing how much faster this borrowed computer was from mine (despite actually being the same age), combined with the outrageousness of the visual effects in that particular movie, combined with the previously mentioned reasons for being ready to make the transition, i decided to reach deep into the savings acount and see if i can make things a little more interesting ............

q.a: if you think they are really doing it wrong, you could try to show them what you think is a better way, but if they are not in the mood to hear it then don't worry too much about it. if they hurt themselves a bit later, hopefully they will be more interested in solutions then. but also be careful not to get wrapped up in wishing everyone played like you. it's easy to feel that way. quite often when i see drummers playing matched grip, i tense up and feel uncomfortable watching them. but in reality, it's 2020 and i think 98% of players are matched now. Or to be more specific, i see a surprising amount of players seemingly not doing anything 'moeler'ish whatsoever in their right hi-hat hand. meaning they're not packaging the strokes in groups of 2, in one single motion together. instead they're just hammering away with their entire arm, for every stroke, going through a lot more effort, looking kind of like they're trying to shake a baby or something. But still, it's on you to sell them on whatever better way you have. kind of like, 'hey, looks pretty tiring the way you're trying to pound out every stroke individually, .... well check this out' and then show them. If you sell it well, they will buy it. But it also comes down to whether it's really right for them or not. If it is, they will know, the first time they see it. and if they don't, then it could be time to start seeing other people. i don't really know, i quit teaching after 2 days
q.q:
Bill, what's up? Can I tell you something? I'm having severe issues with the VAST amounts of
misinformation being spread mainly by vox populi and youtube/internet articles regarding music education.
It's driving me nuts. One of the worst (and I tend to disagree on a lot of things), I think, it's about
the myth regarding strength and exercise needed to play an instrument, as if playing guitar,
piano or even drums required some sort of strong physical competence to the extent professional
athletes do. I truly believe that playing and instruments in general (save some occasions and styles like
flamenco or extreme metal, perhaps) are learned through very simple principles applied through musical
concepts (or just music), with just standard physical well being (in the majority of cases already
achieved) regardless of gender, ethnicity and to some extent age (and there tons of exceptions to my
favor to th is too!! But let's play). I'm seeing people getting hurt trying to get better at their
instruments the wrong way and it breaks my heart. I'm a professional musician and educator and I would
really like to have your take on this. I think you are a true great musician and am a big fan of your work,
by the way! Cheers! P.S.: Just in case, nothing against sports, exercise, fitness or whatever.

q.q:
Hello Bill. which method do you think is the best way to organize your music? I have lots of music on my archive that i've collected over the course of 20 years and that i deeply care about (i hate all sorts of streaming sites). And i've put a lot of effort into shaping my music directory and now i am looking at it thinking if i can use more simplified method.

My music directory goes like this:
I have a main music directory named 'Music'. And then, this directory divides into the music genres, and then into subgenres, then into artists, then into albums (if there's any). Then you find mp3/flac files in those directories. If a song of said artist doesn't belong to any album (ie. single song, etc) it goes into directory named 'singles' in the artist's directory. Also, any songs whose artists i have only one song of, they go to the another directory named 'Singles' in the proper genre/subgenre.

For example, if i wanna listen t o Michae l Jackson's Billie Jean, the path i have to go thru is Music -> Pop -> Michael Jackson - > Thriller, because i have the entire album.

Or, 'Zhi-Vago - Celebrate the Love (Club Mix)' is in Music -> Electronic Music -> Trance -> Dream Trance -> Singles, because it's the only song i have of Zhi-Vago.

When you look at it, it really is good method. All songs from all artists in the same genre is in one place. It makes it easier to listen in Winamp. UNLESS artist have many songs from many different music genres. That's the frustrating part.

Do you think this method is good?

q.a: all songs together in list, organized by date added. played in random order, but searchable by name. would be useful to have it sorted accurately by date released, but let's face it, in a world of potentially infinite songs, the info on that is never gonna be complete unless you spend the rest of your life managing that

q.a: that's pretty simple actually. just find an equirectangular map of the world (that means it's in the shape of a 2 by 1 rectangle) and then map it onto a sphere. q.a: latency hasn't come down enough for it to be good enough for things requiring instant response to user actions. i.e. music production, or phone conversations, or any type of game where it's important to hear an instant sound response to something you did. they're awesome as long as you're just consuming audio tracks (listening to music, not interacting with it) because once the song starts (half second late) it doesn't matter if the whole song is a half second late. Even video watching is ok, because most video players are smart enough to buffer it right so the vid syncs right with the audio. But if you're recording music, you're still looking at at least a 200ms latency. can't play an instrument that way. And this is not good for intimate phone calls either, because as it is, in the digital world, all cell phone calls have about half second delay (or more) already. And this gets worse when you're doing international, or internet calling. wireless ear phones will add at least quarter second delay on top of that. however, besides all that, it is truly awesome to have no wires. but i'd say the latency probably isn't down enough to discontinue the headphone jack just yet
q.q: what's your opinion on wireless ear buds

q.a: true
q.q: a very long time ago, i said something along the lines of, "i'm beginning to think that minor thirds are a very important interval. as in, maybe The Most important." and responded something like, "i see what you mean but you may discover that major seconds are more important." and my idea was--look at the minor thirds in a chord to see where it wants to resolve and how badly. Fm6 wants to resolve to C, G7 and G7b9 want to resolve to C, or to Cm, or if you get sneaky they might go to Am or A, or even F# in some cases. and you look at the common notes here: D, F, Ab, B like to go to chords with their root on C, Eb, F#, A. and a lot of things can be explained by this pattern of minor third series.

q.a: in your first question you didn't give any specifics, you just said ' i think major 3rds might be like the most important thing in the world' . And i believed you, but also true is things like wheels, tables, apples, and so on, could also be similarly thought of as 'the greatest thing in the world'. and probably to have a nice good world you'd probably need a little bit of them all. What you just gave above is wonderful. this has nothing to do with what i had in mind about major seconds being so useful. Melodies come to mind, when thinking about how 'important' major seconds are. And actually, when you first said 'wow major thirds are like really important', my mind immediately went to melodies (you didn't specify what you really meant, like you didn't specify that you were talking about harmonic resolutions, etc) so yeah, i sort of had to guess what you were talking about, and my mind went to melodies. in which case i think it's easy to see why min 3rds and maj 2nds together are hugely important for that game. maj2nds being an absolutely essential building block of anyone's melody kit
q.q: so i thought about your answer and how maybe it could fill some holes in my theory, like how Gsus4 likes to go to G, or how Eaug7 likes to go to E7 before it goes to Am, but ultimately i do not understand why what you said would be true. i know it was a long t ime ago  but if you could explain why you might have said that i would appreciate the closure

q.a: what works best for me is a door touch, kind of a superstition, re-setting my mind from a new listener's point of view, then play the existing song as far as it goes, with metranome, from beginning. then, at the moment when i reach the 'end' (or as far as it goes so far), that's the moment i listen very very carefully. only in that moment, after a clean run through, will i hear the solution. after a window of about 3 to 5 seconds, it gets much much less likely to get a reliable answer. at that point, i can do one of 2 things. i can go ahead and do another door touch and start again, or, if i've done too many run-throughs in a row and burned out the effectiveness of the run-through, i will try to play process of elimination. play detective with it a little. try to at least categorize all imaginable solutions. kind of like on 20 questions where they start by asking 'is it bigger than a breadbox'

This honestly feels similar to how baroque music works. What is your thought process when you compose these things? Is it instinct, or is all of this meticulously planned using advanced music theory? Anyway, sorry for the long question, big fan and fellow musician here trying to analyze your style.

q.q: With regards to the "Click static text" issue, it might be that the text itself doesn't have a clickable action associated with it. Button components have 2 visible elements to it, the outer bounding box, and the text inside it. In typical usage, a mouse click within the bounding box triggers the action of the button. The click action can be associated with the inclosed text, the bounding box, or both. If the text has no clickable action, it seems reasonable that "missing value" would be returned, even if it is able to find the text itself. Automator may have incorrectly assumed the click action was associated with the text instead of the bounding box, or if your program is particularly nasty, the click action may be just associated with a certain x y position on the screen. Somehow you have to get the name of the actual button box,		 and script a click action on that box rather than the text.

q.q: If it is possible to script a click action to a x y positio n, you c an hopefully skip this mess,

q.q: Regarding your AppleScript issue: I've had trouble getting my GUI actions to be recorded by pointing and clicking with a mouse. I DO get the results I want by outlining the keyboard shortcuts for the specific app. Good luck!

AppleScript keycodes: https://eastmanreference.com/complete-list-of-applescript-key-codes

Example used with my video editing software:

tell application "System Events"
key code 0 using {command down} # select all
delay 0.5
key code 44 using {shift down, command down} # select top menu
delay 0.5
repeat 3 times # arrow left over to Action menu
key code 123
end repeat
delay 1
repeat 7 times # arrow down to Templates
